title: Magnetic materials - metallic bars far from magnet

content.description: A student conducts an experiment using a sensitive magnetic field sensor. Three measurements are made with the sensor at the same fixed distance from the north pole of a stationary permanent bar magnet. In Trial <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn></math> only the permanent magnet is near the sensor, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn></math>. In Trial <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>2</mn></math> an initially unmagnetized iron bar is aligned with the bar magnet and positioned at an equal distance on the opposite side of the sensor, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>2</mn></math>. In Trial <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>3</mn></math> an aluminum bar is aligned with the bar magnet and positioned at an equal distance on the opposite side of the sensor, as shown in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>3</mn></math>. The iron and aluminum bars have the same dimensions.
content.question: After each trial, the permanent magnet is removed from the room where the experiment is done. With the permanent bar magnet now removed, the sensor would detect the presence of a magnetic field generated by which, if either, of the two metallic bars in trials <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> and <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> ?

choices.label: Neither the iron nor the aluminum bar
Both the iron and the aluminum bar
